title: 103_hr4131
content: The "Family Unity Promotion Act of 1994" is cited as the short title. It amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section allowing for combined tax returns with separate rates for unmarried individuals. The "Family Unity Promotion Act of 1994" allows married couples to file a combined income tax return with separate taxable incomes. Earned income and pension/annuity income are attributed to the spouse who earned it, while property income is divided based on ownership rights. The "Family Unity Promotion Act of 1994" allows married couples to file a combined income tax return with separate taxable incomes. Income and deductions are attributed to each spouse based on ownership rights and responsibilities. Deductions for retirement savings and alimony are allocated to the respective spouse benefiting from them. Personal exemptions are divided equally between spouses. The "Family Unity Promotion Act of 1994" allows married couples to file a combined income tax return with separate taxable incomes. Deductions, including personal exemptions, additional standard deductions, and other deductions, can be allocated between spouses as they determine. Credits are applied against the joint liability of the couple as if they had filed a joint return. The combined return is treated as a joint return for tax purposes, except for specific sections. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary. The Secretary will prescribe regulations necessary for implementing the "Family Unity Promotion Act of 1994." Amendments are made to tax rates and deductions for unmarried individuals, excluding those defined as married, surviving spouse, or head of household. The basic standard deduction for unmarried individuals is set at $3,000. The tax amendments exclude married, surviving spouse, or head of household individuals. The standard deduction for unmarried individuals is $3,000. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1994. Homemakers are eligible for a full IRA deduction. The amendment to section 219 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for a spousal IRA based on the compensation of both spouses. The limitation for married individuals is the lesser of $2,000 or the sum of the individual's and spouse's compensations. The amendment allows for a spousal IRA based on both spouses' compensation, with limitations for married individuals. The taxable year can be reduced by deductions for the spouse, and certain conditions apply for joint filers. Amendments are made to allow IRAs for spouses who are not active plan participants. Amendments to the tax code include changes to IRA contribution limits and effective dates. SEC. 4. INCREASE IN PERSONAL EXEMPTION FOR CERTAIN DEPENDENT CHILDREN. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the exemption amount to $2,000, or $3,500 for a child under 18. Conforming amendments adjust dollar amounts accordingly. The amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1994.
